misconceptions.name: Implemented an unrelated distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine whether it falls in A (90–100), B (80–89), C (70–79), D (60–69), or F (below 60), and print the correct letter grade.
symptoms: Program reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade.
No variables or logic related to grades or letter outputs.
No conditional (if/else) structure to check numeric ranges.
Output message reports distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment or reusing code for a different textbook/example problem instead of implementing the required grade-to-letter mapping.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem description carefully and start over: read one numeric grade, then use an if/else-if/else chain to test which range it falls into (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade exactly as specified in the prompt.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is devoted to computing distance between two points and contains no references to grades, ranges, or letter output, which clearly does not match the given grade-calculator specification.

evidence.note: All logic relates to reading coordinates and computing distance; there is no grade variable, no conditional ranges, and no letter grade output, indicating the wrong problem was implemented.

misconceptions.name: Submitted Solution for Different Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a Java program to calculate the distance between two 2D points, titled 'DistanceBetweenPoints', instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator (Q3). This results in a complete failure to meet any of the specified rubric criteria.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted the incorrect file, confusing the Grade Calculator assignment with a previous or concurrent assignment regarding geometric calculations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if-else structure) to map it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints'
Reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Performs Euclidean distance calculation using Math.sqrt and Math.pow
No conditional logic present
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted code for an unrelated problem, likely due to file or assignment confusion.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify the assignment instructions and submit the correct file containing the implementation for the Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements the standard distance formula and input procedures for that specific problem, which unequivocally does not match the Grade Calculator requirements.

evidence.note: The entire program implements the 'Distance Between Points' calculation, rendering it irrelevant to the 'Grade Calculator' problem.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem assigned in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or misunderstood which problem they were solving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single grade
Code calculates distance formula instead of grade ranges
Output is a distance value instead of a letter grade
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' does not match problem requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either solved the wrong problem, copy-pasted code from a different assignment, or misread the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the Q3 problem statement. Write a new program that: (1) reads one integer/double grade, (2) uses if-else statements with boolean conditions to check ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.), and (3) prints the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Certainty is absolute: the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculation) with different input/output requirements than the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.

evidence.note: Code reads 4 coordinate values instead of a single grade value as required by Q3

evidence.snippet:
System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n",
                Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Output calculates and prints distance instead of letter grade, using distance formula instead of grade range logic
Class name indicates this is a distance calculation program, not a grade calculator
Complete program solves an entirely different problem with no elements of the grade calculator requirement

misconceptions.name: Reads four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for and reads two (x, y) coordinate pairs rather than a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) from the keyboard.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade value (0–100) from the keyboard using Scanner and store it in one variable for further processing.
symptoms: Prompt asks for "Enter x1 and y1" instead of "Enter grade"
Scanner reads four double values instead of one numeric grade
No variable representing a grade is ever read or stored
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reused code from a distance-formula exercise instead of implementing the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate input with a single numeric grade input, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();` and use that variable in the rest of the program.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All prompts and variables are about coordinates; there is no grade variable or grade prompt at all.

evidence.note: Instead of reading a single numeric grade, the program prompts for and reads four coordinate values.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to map numeric grade ranges to letter grades
misconceptions.description: The program never uses conditional statements to categorize a numeric grade into letter grades A–F; it only computes a distance and prints it.
misconceptions.student_belief: I just need to compute and print the distance between two points; no decision-making logic is required.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to check the numeric grade against specified ranges and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: No if, else if, or else statements in the program
Output is a numeric distance, not a letter grade
No mapping from ranges like 90–100 or 80–89 to letters A or B
misconceptions.root_cause: Focused on solving a different mathematical problem (distance formula) rather than implementing range-based grade classification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if/else-if/else chain based on the grade variable, e.g., `if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... }` and so on, printing the correct letter for each range.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional constructs at all, and the output is a numeric distance instead of any letter grade.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n",
        Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The program prints a computed distance rather than using conditionals to print a letter grade.
Nowhere in the program is there an if/else structure to classify a grade into A, B, C, D, or F.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either mistook the required task or submitted the wrong file entirely, believing this code satisfies the requirement to calculate a letter grade based on a numeric input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must read a single numeric grade from the user and use conditional logic (if-else statements) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: The code asks for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade.
The code uses `Math.sqrt` and `Math.pow` to calculate distance.
There is no conditional logic structure (if/else-if/else) implemented to check grade ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misunderstanding of assignment requirements or incorrect file submission.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt again and start by implementing input reading for a single numeric grade (0-100), followed by the required conditional logic to assign a letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code directly implements the distance formula, which is unrelated to the Grade Calculator problem statement.

evidence.note: The entire code snippet implements a solution for calculating the distance between two points, not grading, failing all aspects of the Grade Calculator task.

misconceptions.name: Mismatch of Class Name to Problem
misconceptions.description: The class name, 'DistanceBetweenPoints', reflects a different problem than the Grade Calculator (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely reused a file or forgot to rename the program file after implementing a different task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The class name should be descriptive of the required functionality, such as 'GradeCalculator'.
symptoms: Class name does not match assignment context.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete refactoring or submission of an incorrect file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the class name accurately reflects the program's purpose for better organization and readability.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The filename and class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' is strong evidence that the code is focused on a geometry problem, not grade calculation.

evidence.note: The class name is inappropriate for a Grade Calculator program.

misconceptions.name: Submitted wrong program entirely
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a distance calculation program instead of a grade calculator. The entire solution is for a different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misunderstood the assignment entirely or submitted code from a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade and using conditional statements to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F).
symptoms: Code reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Implement a program that reads a single grade value and uses if/else statements to check which range it falls into, then output the corresponding letter.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n",
